turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Hey Josie. It's Josie, right?

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Can I just say--I totally love Ex- Lax.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: wait, rewind. Do you really think she hooked-up with our Rob? They're so--different.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Sometimes opposites attract.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Wannabes. Kirsten transitioned last year.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Her dad sold a car to Leonardo Di Caprio's uncle and before he picked it up, her dad let us all sit in it and take pictures.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Oh-my-God. You totally ripped off my Malibu Barbie idea.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Uh uh. I'm Disco Barbie.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: You guys--what is the one thing that could ruin my senior prom?

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: That you would trip on your Barbie heels and I'd get named prom queen?  Did I say that out loud?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: That'll teach me to wear white after Labor Day.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Umm- I don't think you're supposed to wear white jeans after 1983.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: I think it's pronounced gauche.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yeah it's French. There's no accent aigue, so the e is soft.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Josie, you have totally transitioned.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Transitioned?

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: You crossed over.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: : Wait. Do you know any gay guys?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: He is totally crunching on you.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Do I want to be crunched?

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: By Guy?

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Hey Josie- who did Archie date Betty or Veronica?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Betty.

turns.speaker: GIBBY
turns.text: Don't tell me... You're Medieval Barbie.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rosalind and Orlando.  From "As You Like It"?  Shakespeare?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Computer's down. Septuplets story. I need it back by five. Hopefully the copy's not a mess.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It is hoped that it's not a mess. "Hopefully" is an adverb. It means "with hope". You have it defining the copy, and I'm pretty sure the copy doesn't have feelings.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Well, excuse me for caring about words.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: So. You and Roger in Op/Ed.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: How many times have I fired her?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Five-- Six--

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Eh.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Hey Gus--did you see the story idea I left on your desk?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah--the blind foster home mother. It was good. I got Cahoon on it.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Geller, we've been over this. You're a great copy editor. Maybe my best copy editor. You're not a reporter.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You've done five of my ideas.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You know what separates us office flunkies from the reporters?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: They don't have to be in the office Christmas show?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: A flack jacket.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: A--flack jacket.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks he can write. But a journalist gets in there, right where the bombs are. He's aggressive. Grabs the bull by the balls.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You don't think I can grab bulls' balls?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Geller, you don't want a reporter's life. They're very--messy. You're all about order. Control. And getting me my copy by five.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Hey--I can be out of control.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Don't worry, I'll straighten all this out.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: But I don't want it straightened out.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Geller, this is way out of your league.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It's my dad. He worries.  Hi, Dad. I miss you too.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You're a sick puppy, Geller.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It's an expose on cafeteria food.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: And you're leading with the terrible truth about cole slaw?!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Well, the bulk of it will be about the pimento loaf--

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Geller...you wanna be a reporter? Take a look at what sells! Sex scandals. Bribery. People jumping off buildings. So unless a kid just killed himself because he was being paid to have sex with the school mascot in a big vat of this cole slaw, you got nothing!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: No, I am appalled that I have a reporter in there, undercover, for almost three weeks now- I had to read about this in the Tribune.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh. Right.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Responding officers found minors, marijuana, and cheap wine coolers when they responded to a call to break up a party at what Southglen High Schoolers have come to call "The Court." Seventeen-year-old Kristen Rey says, "Yeah, everyone who's anyone is at The Court on Saturday night."

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Kristen got a quote?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yes, urm, she's right. I have learned it is a very popular place for the young people to go.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Have you been there?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Uhh, no.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Have you been to any parties?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Well, how would you define to parties"? Because we ordered a deli platter at this one Denominator drill session--

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: This is where the stories are. You are going to become friends with these people. You are going to party with them. You are going to hang out with them on weekends. When they go to prom, you are going to be in their same damn limo!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Gus I, the popular kids and I, we just don't- I mean, I don't think I can do this.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Do you even know these kids?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: They hid my car--

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Get to know them. Very well. Your job and my job depends on it.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Depend on it. No s. Your subject is plural.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: OUT!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Gus?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: No, it's the Great and Powerful Oz. Now listen--you're in over your head. This is how it's gonna work. I review the tapes, I find your story.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: What if I say no?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I bet Good Housekeeping would go gaga over the cole slaw piece.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That's your story!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You're crazy. I can't--I can't-no. No.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: It's got it all--sex, intrigue, immorality in the education system--

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: He's my teacher!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: And that's the best part.  "Teacher-Student Relations: How close is too close?" We're gonna blow the lid off it!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: There is no lid! Nothing's going on between Sam and me. Coulson. Mr. Sam Coulson and me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not yet. Every person in this office comes in here and watches you guys! It's like the goddamn Young and the Restless! Rigfort's salivating over it.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You already pitched this to Rigfort?!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Your story was Rigfort's baby. We were scooped! We've got nothing. Zippo. You totally and completely screwed both of us.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Maybe I could talk to Rigfort, you know, tell him the whole story.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I'll tell you a story. It's about this shy copy editor who makes a mockery of herself and her boss when she completely botches her first assignment as a reporter.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yes you are. A guy. Guy. Quite a guy. Oh my. Look at that--I rhymed.  Yikes.  Bikes!

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Are you in special ed?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh my god.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Dude, you rock!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rob's?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Yeah, you gonna be there?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Hey there.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Hey. There.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Maybe we should go in a different room?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: I already checked. There are some pretty serious couples in there.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: I'm sure you've probably heard that I want to ask you, but I'd like to know if you'd go to prom with me. I know we Didn't hit it off right at the beginning but-

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yes. I'll go. Yes.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Rufus.  But I don't even know where you live.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You know what?  Why don't you just pick me up here? We could all share a limo.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Cool. I'll catch you later.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: You having fun?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh yeah. The best. Josie takes in the spectacle around her.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Hey--what are you thinking about?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Shakespeare. How he described a night like this--"Look how the floor of heaven is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold".  What about you? What are you thinking about?

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: My sword.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: GUY
turns.text: Josie, you rock my world. You're like the most amazing girl I've ever dated. You're so smart and fun and crazy! You rock my world.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You said that already.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: God, I can't do this.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Maybe because we're not supposed to be having sex with bananas.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: You know what, though? I feel like I'm really ready to do it. To have sex for the first time.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Wow. That's big. I mean sex is a really big deal. You shouldn't do it until you know you've found the right person.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You know, Adele penguins pick one mate. They spend their whole life looking for that one other penguin and when they find it, they know. That's the penguin they stay with for the rest of their lives.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: But I'm not a penguin.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Hey Rob, what's going on?

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: I'm Rob's prom date.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: That is so--weird that you name your car.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No it's not. Guys name their penises.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Okaaaay....  That car's going to bankrupt you.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: She just needs a new windshield wiper.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Because I bought the windshield last week. I'm a hubcap away from owning more of Bambi than you do.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rob, take the money, okay? It's no big deal.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, it is. It's just one more thing to add to your "things that make you a better person than me" list.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Better person than I.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: See!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I know this woman. She works in admissions at Lakeshore Community? She might be able to get you in for the Fall semester. Maybe she could get you the baseball scholarship, and I could help and--

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I'm not going to college, Jos. And I'm not playing anymore baseball. This is my life.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: This--this is a luau that sells packing material!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Someday this luau is going to be all mine!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: How can you just give up like that? You had a real shot at playing college ball and you let one case of mono stop everything. Don't you want more? To move out of Mom and Dad's? Pay your own bills?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh yay! And then I could be as happy as you!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: For your information, I am very happy. Deliriously happy. I lead a very happy life!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It's just for a couple of months.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: You can't just "borrow" my car for a couple of months! That's like ten years in Bambi life!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I'll give you my Buick Le Sabre.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Wow. This must be big.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I got an assignment from the paper. I'm going undercover. Back to high school.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: What!?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Do you remember high school?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It was a long time ago -

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Don't you remember what they called you?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Josie Grossie.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I know. I came up with it.  You look nauseous.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Nauseated. I look nauseated. Oh God.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Are mom and dad here?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No. They're at the Franklin Hint Expo at the Skokie Holiday Inn.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, I mean, no big whoop.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I can't do this.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: These girls are high schoolers? Damn, we've got some underage hotties on our hands, here!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Gus insists that I become friends with these kids. The popular kids. It's impossible.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Why is that impossible?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rob, you don't know how it was for me back in high school. No one ever threw juice boxes at you in the hallway. You never dreamed about being popular- you already were. All I wanted was to be accepted, and they just fucking tortured me. I can't do all that again. I can't go back to Southglen South.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Oh my God! You're at Southglen South? They have a killer baseball team.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rob. Please focus.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Jos, you've been to college, you're successful, you wash your hair now-- you're not Josie Grossie anymore.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Don't you realize how much I wanted to be you in high school? Just for one minute to feel what it was like to be popular?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Come on! It's not that hard. All you need is one person. Once the right person thinks you're cool, you're in. Everyone else will be too scared to question it.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Is that true?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Little known fact.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Look, don't you wanna show them - Gus, Billy Prince, yourself--that you're not freaked out by the cool kids anymore? That you can go in there, be friends with them, and get your story?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yes, desperately.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Plus, if you quit you're no better than me.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Better than I...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: That's the spirit!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I've been in a horrible accident. This is a coma-induced nightmare.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No. Josie, this is real.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Are you crazy?! You can't do this.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: This is it Jos! This is my ninth inning! The game isn't over--I just thought it was!  I get on the Southglen baseball team, the right scout sees me-- I'm into the minors- it's game time!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You're twenty-three years old!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: With the reading comprehension of a fifteen year old! Plus, I'm popular... You want to be popular... I can recognize a cry for help when I see one.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Hear one.  Rob, this is so like you. You know, you can't just come in here and be popular in just one day.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Really?  Rob-, that girl is sixteen.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: And a gymnast!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: She's sixteen years old, Rob. That's totally and completely illegal.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Wow, Josie- you look really-

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rufus?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yes. Exactly. Major Rufus.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thanks. And what are -

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Duh. Tom Cruise. "Risky Business".

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Rob--thanks. For everything. This is really happening. I never thought--

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Josie, finally. I just wanted to come over and make sure you're okay.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No- not really, Josie. NOT REALLY. How could you do that to me?  I helped you. I got you everything you wanted. And how do you repay me- you blow everything TWO DAYS before pro scouts come to see me play. Once they had seen me really play- they wouldn't have given a shit about my age.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: wasn't even thinking about-

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, you weren't. Don't you realize the only time I was really happy in the last five years was when I was playing ball with those guys?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I-

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: No, shut up, Josie. Just shut up.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hi, everyone.  I don t think we've met. I'm Sam Coulson- although for some reason the school has this thing about not letting you guys call me Sam.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I'm Josie. Geller. I think the school would probably be pretty comfortable with you calling, me that. Josie.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Whoa. Deja Vu.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Sorry. Forgetful.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Dorothy Parker--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You like her?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I love the way she writes.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Not the happiest of souls.  "Art is a form of catharsis, and love is a permanent flop."

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: But I think she wanted to be happy, that's why she wrote. I mean, she was still writing about love, right?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: True. I guess she hadn't completely given up hope.  Are you sure you're seventeen?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Sure, why?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Because seventeen-year-olds do not like writers from the '30's. They don't even like people in their 30's.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Well, I'm definitely seventeen and  now definitely late--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hey, Josie, hold on.  You've been hiding something from me.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh I don't think so.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Your writing. It's amazing, Josie. You're really talented. And far less depressing than Dorothy Parker.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So what are you thinking for college?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: College. Haven't really thought about it.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That's crazy. I'll get you some applications.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh no no no no no. See, my family, we don't go to college.  We just go right into sheep herding.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Josie you owe it to yourself to go. For your writing. You're a natural.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thanks. Wow. That's--really nice to hear.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Josie, you're different. When you speak in class, I can tell--You actually feel the words--  in here. They're alive. Like-Eurdora Welty talked about the word it moon"? How for her it was like a Concord grape. "That Grandpa took off his vine and gave to me to suck out of its skin--"

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: This seat taken?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Are you--scared?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm gonna tell you something here, and I hope it doesn't undermine my position as an authority figure. I'm a little afraid of heights.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You're afraid of the Ferris wheel.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Actually, it's more the plunging head first into the crowd part that gets me.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh right. The Spiderman incident.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You remember that story?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Of course. I remember everything from your class.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yoooooow.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Don't look down!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Okay This is okay. Smooth.  Can I ask you something? Do you think I tell too many stories in class?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: That's what makes you interesting.  As a teacher.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: God, I would love to think I'm an interesting teacher. I mean, I had maybe one or two teachers in high school who had any passion at all.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You do. Seem to. Have passion. In the classroom.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You have to say that. You're my student.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I don't have to say that.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Boys.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'd like to tell you that we all grow out of it, but that's a lie. Some of us will always be rattling cages.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Why do you do that?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know. And you know what's scary--when you get older it just gets more confusing. I've spent the last ten years with women who are basically all wrong for me.  You know what, I shouldn't be talking about this stuff with you.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: That's okay. It's nice to have someone to talk to--

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You have to say that. You're my teacher.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I shouldn't say that, because I'm your teacher.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Thanks, Josie. This wasn't as bad as I thought.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: When are you going to open your eyes?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm thinking when I'm home.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You're really doing a great job here, Josie. I like your "can do" attitude.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thanks.  They weren't related to Humpty Dumpty, were they? Tweedle Dum and Tweedle Dee?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Maybe distant cousins. They did have that egg shape in common.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: But Humpty Dumpty was alone.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: That's sad, isn't it? He had to sit on that wall all by himself. He deserved to have somebody.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: That's really what we all need, right? Someone to sit up on the wall with us--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah. To watch the world go by.--

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: To put us back together again when we fall.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Our penguin, right?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Do you think you'll find her?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yeah, actually I do.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh my God! I almost forgot--I got you a meeting with the admissions guy from Dartmouth!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: What! But--I wasn't even going to go to college--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, I know, but I pulled some strings, got him to look at your writing, and he agreed to meet you.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Oh--yikes!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: told him  --if I'm wrong about this girl, you can take away my teaching certificate!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Wow. You believe in me that much--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Of course I do. Josie, you owe it to yourself--to your writing, to go to college. You're a great writer. You just have to find your story.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Josie--you make a really beautiful prom queen.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Thanks. So do you.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Proms always make me sad. They're so final. Graduation. Everyone's scattering, moving on.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Well, are you here with anybody?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: No, I'm alone.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: It's weird because "prom" is actually from the word "promenade". And you can't really promenade alone, can you?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: So--have you thought anymore about Dartmouth?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Yeah, I have.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: "Surprise!" you were doing a story on me?!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: No, surprise, I thought you'd be--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: What? Happy? Why? Because it turns out all along that I was allowed to be attracted to you?

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: You were attracted to me?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Goddamnit, Josie! Drop the act. Do you have any idea what I went through every night because of you?!  I was attracted to a 17 year old! When I wasn't taking cold showers, I was trying to figure out what the hell I was going to do when I couldn't teach anymore! I thought I was the one being unethical.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Wait, I was going to tell you--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You set me up. For a story.  You know what's crazy? I was actually considering waiting for you.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: But now you don't have to--

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Now I don't want to! I bought all of your penguin crap. I thought I found her--the right one! And the problem was she was too young! No - the problem was--she didn't even exist!

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I did exist. I do exist. I'm the same person!

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: The person I cared about wouldn't have done this. Everything out of your mouth has been a complete lie. I don't know you at all. For all I know you could hate Dorothy Parker.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I don't! Look, you could get to know me, again.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Please. Please don't walk away.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I just can't look at you the same way.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I told you you could write, Josie Geller.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: I finally found my story.

turns.speaker: SHEILA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHEILA
turns.text: Billy Prince is asking you to prom.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SHEILA
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: JOSIE
turns.text: The poem! I knew he liked the poem!  Billy Prince is asking me to the prom.

turns.speaker: SHEILA
turns.text: That's what I'm saying.

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: That is so sad --

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: I know, like five chickens had to die just so she could look that stupid.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Kirsten, that bran muffin has like 75 fat grams.

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: Nah uh.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Into our group.

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: It's really hard to do. Some kids try for all of-high school and never make it.

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: We'd love to transition a gay guy into the group.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: We're very evolved.

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: Josie, you look Rufus.

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: Who are you guys?

turns.speaker: KRISTEN
turns.text: You ruined the whole thing!

turns.speaker: KIRSTEN
turns.text: You so do not deserve to be prom queen.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Hey Monty--you think we'll get any business today?

turns.speaker: MONTY
turns.text: I'm handing out a free lei to every customer! What do you think?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I think maybe people are scared off by the tiki torches.

turns.speaker: MONTY
turns.text: Change is scary. Robbie, let me tell you a little something about the mail business. I've been in it over thirty years. And in those thirty years, the only thing that's changed is the Elvis stamp and some gun laws. People are bored! They wanna shake things up!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: I thought people just wanted their mail delivered on time.

turns.speaker: MONTY
turns.text: Aloha! Welcome!

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Relax, Monty. It's just my sister.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Hi. I'm Tracy and I'm sixteen and I'm a gymnast and I don't have a boyfriend...

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Thank you.  I'm Rob.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Duh.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Rob, what do you want to be when you grow up?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Well, a ball player.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: No, I know. But, what if you don't make it? 'I mean, you don t Want to be working at a mail place the rest of your life. It's okay for an after school job, but, come on, "hi, I'm Rob and I run the Tiki Post"?! Totally lame.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Are you having fun?

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Yeah. Definitely.

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Good. Gibby gave me champagne.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Maybe we should sit.

turns.speaker: ROB
turns.text: Wow - I-

turns.speaker: TRACY
turns.text: Rob, I mean it. I want you to be my first. Me and you. Once the floor stops spinning, let's have sex.

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: By name.

turns.speaker: LOCK
turns.text: Lock.

turns.speaker: LOCK
turns.text: I wish my cohorts weren't so dumb.

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: I'm not the dumb one...

turns.speaker: LOCK
turns.text: I've got something, listen now, This one is real good, you'll see. We'll send a present to his door Upon there'll be a note to read.

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: Now in the box, we'll wait and hide Until his curiosity Entices him to look inside...

turns.speaker: LOCK
turns.text: We followed your instructions.

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: We went through the door...

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: He <u>has</u> to know...

turns.speaker: LOCK
turns.text: Everybody knows about--

turns.speaker: SHOCK
turns.text: Shock.

turns.speaker: BARREL
turns.text: Barrel.
